qas.question: What is the biological interaction where a predator feeds on its prey called?
The act of predation typically results in what for the prey?
What is the consumption of dead organic matter called?
Why do parasitic species lay their eggs on their prey?

answers.text: their offspring to feed on its decaying corpse

qas.question: The evolutionary arms race between prey and predator has resulted in what?

context: <a0_0>Predation<a0_0/> is a biological interaction where a predator (a heterotroph that is hunting) feeds on its prey (the organism that is attacked). Predators may or may not kill their prey prior to feeding on them, but the act of predation almost always results in the <a1_0>death<a1_0/> of the prey. The other main category of consumption is <a2_0>detritivory<a2_0/>, the consumption of dead organic matter. It can at times be difficult to separate the two feeding behaviours, for example, where parasitic species prey on a host organism and then lay their eggs on it for <a3_0>their offspring to feed on its decaying corpse<a3_0/>. Selective pressures imposed on one another has led to an evolutionary arms race between prey and predator, resulting in <a4_0>various antipredator adaptations<a4_0/>.
